vsan.services.disabled.featureDescriptio: VMware vSAN uses a software-defined approach that creates shared storage for virtual machines. It virtualizes the local physical storage resources of ESXi hosts and turns them into pools of storage that can be divided and assigned to virtual machines and applications according to their quality-of-service requirements. vSAN is implemented directly in the ESXi hypervisor.

vsan.upgrade.manage.dialog.content.norma: Upgrading the vSAN on-disk format is a long running operation. Once you upgrade the on-disk format, you cannot rollback software on the hosts or add certain older hosts to the cluster, as explained in this
. This operation upgrades one disk group at a time. It evacuates all data stored on each disk group, removes the old vSAN format, and re-adds the disk groups to vSAN with the new format.
No data will be moved as part of this operation. Once you upgrade the on-disk format, you cannot rollback software on the hosts or add certain older hosts to the cluster, as explained in this
. This operation upgrades one disk group at a time.

vsan.monitor.health.disk.format.udpate.d: Converting the vSAN on-disk format is a long running operation. Make sure you have all the ESXi hosts from the vSAN cluster added to the vCenter cluster. Also make sure that all vSAN configuration in vCenter is accurate (including host fault domain settings, de-duplication settings, encryption settings, and so on) because any misconfiguration pushed down at this stage can reconfigure this vSAN cluster, causing server side-effects.

vsan.monitor.health.remediate.fileservic: Containers in hosts with an unbalanced workload might be moved to other hosts to balance the workload. The rebalance might impact any host in this cluster, not just the hosts with warnings.

During the rebalance, I/O is disrupted to SMB shares located in containers that have moved. Workloads running on NFS shares are not disrupted. The rebalance can take up to 30 minutes depending on the cluster size, schedule a maintenance window for the rebalance if necessary.
Start the rebalance task if your applications running on SMB shares can tolerate a short (usually less than 5 minutes) IO disruption.
Otherwise, schedule a maintenance window for the rebalance task.

configureVsan.settings.computeOnly.descr: An HCI Mesh compute cluster is a vSAN-enabled cluster that does not have any storage capabilities itself, but mounts other vSAN datastores within the same datacenter.
configureVsan.settings.spaceEfficiency.c: Compression improves the total cost of ownership by reducing the data stored on your physical disks.
configureVsan.settings.spaceEfficiency.d: Deduplication and compression improves the total cost of ownership by reducing the data stored on your physical disks. Deduplication and compression only works for all-flash disk groups. Creating hybrid disk groups is not allowed when deduplication and compression is turned on.

configureVsan.settings.wipeDiskDescripti: This setting directs vSAN to wipe existing data from the storage devices before they are encrypted. This option can significantly increase the time to process each disk, so do not choose it unless you have unwanted data on the disks.
configureVsan.settings.allowReducedRedun: By selecting this option, you agree that vSAN can reduce the protection level of your VMs, if needed, during the operations of changing deduplication and compression or Encryption state. This option is only usable if your setup is at the limit of the protection level, configured by the Storage policy of a specific VM.
vsan.generalConfig.encryptionWarning: These settings require all disks to be reformatted. Moving large amount of stored data might be slow and temporarily decrease the performance of the cluster.
configureVsan.settings.largeScaleCluster: By default, vSAN cluster can only grow up to 32 nodes. By setting this option, the vSAN cluster is allowed to grow up to a larger scale, at maximum of 64 nodes. If this option is changed before the cluster configuration, it can be applied at host side immediately but if it is changed on later, all hosts are required to reboot to apply this change.

vsan.health.monitor.proactive.vmCreation: This test creates a very simple tiny VM on every host. If that creation succeeds, the VM gets deleted and it can be concluded that a lot of aspects of vSAN are operational. The management stack are all operational on all hosts, vSAN network plumbing is working, creation/deletion and IO to objects on vSAN is working, etc. Doing such an active test can find issues that passive health findings may not be able to detect. By doing so systemically it is also very easy to isolate any particular faulty host and then take steps to remedy.
vsan.health.monitor.proactive.networkPer: This test is designed to assess the network bandwidth of the hosts. The test is performed between the hosts in a ring structure, i.e. every host sends packets to its next host while receives from the previous. The test will examine the network bandwidth that can be achieved between hosts and will report warning if the bandwidth is less than 850Mbps. Note: the available network bandwidth has critical impact to the overall vSAN performance.
vsan.health.monitor.proactive.warning.vm: Run the virtual machines creation test now?
VM creation test takes 20-40 seconds in the common case, and at most 180 seconds in case of timeouts. One VM create and one delete task are spawned per host and they show up in the task console.
vsan.health.monitor.proactive.warning.ne: Run the multicast performance test now?
Multicast performance test is designed to assess if there is connectivity issue and if the network bandwidth between the hosts can satisfy the requirements of vSAN.
Run the Network performance test now?
Network performance test is designed to assess if there is connectivity issue and if the network bandwidth between the hosts can satisfy the requirements of vSAN.

vsan.monitor.capacity.analysis.oversubsc: If all thin provisioned VMs and user objects are used at full capacity
The oversubscription ratio applies to available capacity, which is the total capacity minus the reserved capacity.
Oversubscription calculation considers all VMs, user objects, and storage policy overhead. Oversubscription calculation does not consider vSAN namespace and swap objects.

The predicted oversubscription usage will not be accurate considering deduplication and compression, because the actual size after dedup will vary based on the real data redundancy. Use the estimation just as a rough estimate.

Static IP address, subnet masks and gateway for file servers

vsan.fileservices.affinitySite.label: Affinity site

vsan.fileservices.configure.affinitySite: To reduce the cross-site traffic latency, you can configure the site affinity for the file server to locate the file servers to the specified site. The file server failovers to the other site when the site failure happens to the specified site, and fallbacks when it is recovered. Configure more file servers to one site if more workloads can be expected from a certain site. The default site affinity is 'Either', which means the file server is not affinized to any site.
vsan.fileservices.share.create.affinityS: Configure the affinity site for the file share when a shorter latency is needed for visiting the file share from a certain site. The default value of affinity site of a file share is Either, which means the file share is placed randomly to any site.

Migration Threshold measures how much imbalance across hosts in the cluster is acceptable based on CPU and memory loads. Recommendations are generated automatically based on resources demanded by the virtual machines, resource allocation settings (reservations, limits, and shares), and the resources provided by each host. The lower the setting value, the more imbalance is tolerated between hosts.
